subject: Critical Thinking
title: Base Rate Neglect: Ignoring the Background Numbers
description: Learn Base Rate Neglect: Ignoring the Background Numbers in one minute.

hook.text: A test is 99% accurate. You test positive for a rare disease. What's the chance you actually have it?

buildup.text: Base rate neglect: ignoring how common something is in the general population when evaluating evidence.

discovery.text: If a disease affects 1 in 10,000 and the test has 1% false positives, ~99 false alarms occur for every true case.

twist.text: Doctors fall for this too. Studies show physicians dramatically overestimate the meaning of positive test results.

climax.text: Bayes' Theorem is the mathematical fix â€” it forces you to factor in the base rate before updating beliefs.

quiz.question: Why can a 99% accurate test still produce mostly false positives?
options: If the condition is rare, false positives vastly outnumber true positives
The math doesn't apply to medicine
